dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking ahead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three... up. The lifeless body of a fair-sized man comes CRASHING into SIRENS closer.  A man seen only in silhouette leans in to over the corpse.  A second man looks in, then pulls the f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cookie-cutter subdivision.  Old pine trees poke through blankets the neighborhood.  HOWARD (30s), a burly outdoor unload a new snowmobile from the back of his pickup.  TED 20s) half hidden under a heavy dress coat, walks down the Howard's driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need a hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Could ya grab me those two by eights? Ted walks up the driveway, grabs the wood slats, makes a them against the rear bumper. HOWARD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Howard maneuvers the snowmobile down the ramp, his back t Ted -- who has taken out a small cam-corder and is taping HOWARD (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell ya, it may look fast but it sure ain't light.  You guy who just moved in to the Stevens old house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Name's Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Ted, I'm Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Howard.  What is that, an Arctic Cat? What do those go for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard finally has the snowmobile on the ground.  He's br pulls off his mitt to shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More than I could normally afford, I'll tell ya. (seeing the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  What do you think you're you doing? As Ted and Howard continue to talk, we PULL BACK to revea Ted's video playing on a VCR that is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of office WORKERS look on, very much impressed, a Howard stares at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard, you seem like a reasonable kind of guy. Lets you and me talk. TIGHT ON: WATTERS at his nearby cubicle, typing frenetica At first, he appears to be working, until we realize that pixilated Zombies die in silent anguish beneath an unholy Miami Dolphins sticker is the sole cubicle decoration. As the tape finishes, a smattering of APPLAUSE from his c gives a small wave over the cubicle wall. TED (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Just happy to give something back to Liberty Capital... (to himself - bitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all they've done for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM (30s), Native-American Alaskan walks over. Ted immedi that turns the screen to a spread-sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was really cool.  It was like... watching "Cops".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was pretty spry for a man with a herniated disc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I don't want to bitch or anything, but you were supposed to take me along on that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you know this, but the sooner they think I can handle calls on my own, the sooner they'll kick you back down south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been hearing that for 13 months and six days, Cam.  After a while, it gets a little old. (off Cam's look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, okay. Good enough.  Cam moves off.  Back to the zombie blood ba RINGS.  Ted picks up, his eyes never wavering from the go computer game. TED (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claims, Ted Watters.  Sure. A final key stroke separates one last zombie from its ent

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON
dialogues.text: We PULL BACK to see the walls lined with souvenirs of a l edge of the wilderness; citations from the Rotarians, pic hockey teams... We are -- FRANK BRANCH (50s), a mid-level management type sits acro BARNELL (40s), a mild-mannered everyman wrapped in a chea takes in the display.  The two men sit in silence, smilin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's... quite the fish. Branch is about to answer when Ted enters with a slim fil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Barnell, Ted Watters. Handshakes.  Paul makes steady eye contact.  Ted notices. BRANCH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnell wants to talk to us about his brother's life insurance policy. Ted sits and flips open the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Raymond.  You see, as I've already explained to Mr. Branch, he's been gone for five years now, and I thought it might be time to... move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By move on you mean...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...cash in Raymond's policy. Ted smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought, well, it's pretty unlikely he's still ali My Dad always wanted us to be able to look after each other if anything should ever happen.  And to be frank, money's a little --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand Mr. Barnell, but here's the thing. With no actual body, under Alaskan statutes a person must be missing for seven years before he or she can be legally declared dead and that's not withstanding an investigation period where concerned parties can take up to another year to file interventions concerning the motion.  So, even though your brother's status is undetermined at this point, there's really very little we can do for you. Ted flips the file shut.  Case closed.  Branch, not entir demeanor, forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we are extremely sorry for your loss. Branch looks at Ted.  Ted turns to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city skyline rises in the distance as heat vents belc rapidly setting sun.  But that's miles away.  Here on the failing five store strip mall; a "Porn-a-copia" XXX Video small engine repair shop, fish and chips joint and the "B travel agency.  We might notice a big trash dumpster in t a Ford Taurus, pulls onto the parking pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul driving, talking on his cell phone and balancing a b travel coffee mug at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, hang on.  First off, how did you get my cell number?  (Beat)  Because it's for mechanical and medical emergencies only. Paul, wound up, taps his brakes too hard.  His mug falls, coffee proceeds to soak a stack of papers. PAUL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. (back into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not...  I just... give me a second here. Paul parks his car, gathers the soggy papers and gets out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, still on the phone, carries the papers to the dumps

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and that check went out a week ago.  I watched my secretary write it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.  Paul opens the lid.  The phone is cradled in his soggy page to make sure he's not tossing anything importa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't know.  I, I, I have no clue.  Could it possibly be a problem on your end?  So the electric company never makes a...  Look, I pay my bills.  I'm a Rotarian for goodness -- Paul looks over to see some MEN from Rodney's Repo Ranch the front door of his office.  Distracted for a moment, t into the trash. Paul, muttering, leans in to get it.  He pushes aside an guided by the faint sound of the other person STILL TALKI PAUL'S POV: of THE BODY-- a 40-ish White (well, a little a cheap suit.  Paul's phone lies across the corpse's mout talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnell?  Mr. Barnell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOUT as Paul jumps back from the dumpster. The lid CRA he scrambles/slides away.  He takes a moment to compose h realizes his phone is still in there. He opens the dumpster lid and very quickly reaches in, gr hurries off.  The lid CRASHES shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hung up.  Paul dials 911, looks back at the dumpster, thi hits END.  He stands there, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul back in his office, staring out the window with a pe dumpster.  He can't take his eyes off it. Behind him, the Repo-Men are picking up a newish computer walking toward the door.  He's oblivious. At the sound of a TRUCK, his head snaps around.  It's a g instead of heading to the dumpster, it rumbles past on th takes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul backs his Ford Taurus up to the dumpster, pops the t make sure he's alone then steps up on the rear bumper, op clambers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.  The fridge door opens, the light revealing severa in the foreground.  Behind the beverages, a garage where Paul struggles with the lifeles man against the hood of his car, gives him a quick once o wounds.  Nothing. Paul moves to the fridge, starts to pull things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jodie, an annoyingly small dog, enters the garage from th sniffing around the body.  A new chew toy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the sound)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jodie, no!  Not for dogs! He SHOOS the dog back into the house.  Paul moves back to the door and, with great effort picks up the dead man and inside.  Only problem... The man's legs don't want to fit.  Paul leans down and gr appendage.  He grits his teeth, looks away as he kicks at sideways. Paul fights nausea.  But with the leg now out of joint, t breathing heavy, leans against the door. PAUL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK then.  OK. He packs in the remaining space with beer and pop bottles he shuts the door, Paul reaches in and sets the fridge te (the coldest setting). A padlock and chain come from the base of a propane BBQ. fridge, the lock SNAPS it in place.  Paul spots some left kicks them to the corner and walks into the house, trying PAUL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Honey.  Any mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted drives home through a wooded section of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted checks out various radio stations, hating everything. playing "Escape (The piГ±a Colada Song)" when he looks up jams on the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted car slides toward a moose that has wandered into the The car stops about five feet away. The moose looks at Ted.  Ted looks back, wondering what h deserve the life he's stuck with.  After a moment, the mo drives on.

dialogues.speaker: C18 INT TED'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON: A COMPUTER SCREEN where swirling signs of the Z screen saver.  PULL BACK TO REVEAL we are -- A telephone cord runs from the computer to the headset of smart and dressed in a tight University of Alaska T-shirt feet up on the desk as she flips through a copy of "Cosmo It's a medium sized apartment, littered with guy stuff al advancing signs of feminine influence. The phone RINGS.  Tiffany hits the space bar.  The caller screen.  By the second ring, an electronic timer kicks in the caller appears with name, address, background, pets.. "enter."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into her headset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychic Pals.  How are you today... Mr. Williams? (pause - she listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we are all registered psychics here.  I just had a feeling you'd be calling.  What's up? A KEY IN THE DOOR.  A tired Ted walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Tiff. Tiffany looks up, then holds up a file folder with the wo SHHHHHH!" in big black letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to caller)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your TV remote control?  Okay. Ted SIGHS, gives her a quick peck on the cheek as he wres gear and heads to the kitchen. TIFFANY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to clear your mind... Ted looks into the fridge, making up new words to the son

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "If you like frozen enchiladas, getting caught in the rain.  If you're not into...something brownish." Ted pulls out some Tupperware, tries to figure out what's wearing her headset, appears behind him, grabs a Diet Cok and kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's stew.  I'm not sure it's still good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you with a customer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're concentrating. Ted grabs a fork, takes the pot and sits at the table.  T desk and flips through her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through a mouthful of food)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?  How's the tea leaf business today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've decided from now on to ignore you when you're ignorant about my work.  And it's going very well thank you. (reconnecting to the caller)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Williams, I'm seeing sofa cushions.  Do you have a sofa?  Good.  Glad I could help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You here from that software distributor guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I did crack that code problem.  You know how sometimes when you're running Beta versions you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a boo-boo, but I fixed it. (another call comes in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychic Pals, how are you today, Carol?  Now I thought we'd agreed God is everywhere, but not specifically in your coffee pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, Tiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, Ted.  Do I tell you how to do your job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding... kind of)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but then again I'm not a computer aided pseudo psychic, so if you're looking for moral equivalence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you say anything else that may keep us from having sex ever again, let me ask you something... She picks up her magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiff, please.  I always get these wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we keep trying.  Now, Love is Sacrifice test. (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were in a life raft with me and there was only enough water --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have a customer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the caller)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol?  God says he's busy with a famine right now, but you should keep praying.  Cool. She hangs up.  Turns back to Ted, about to pick up where

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm not doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a stupid quiz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. The PHONE RINGS.  Tiffany bolts to her desk, sits, spins answers the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychic Pals.  Is this the first time you've called us Mrs...? Tiffany at her computer, enters the name "Margaret Barnel Tiffany works a "mute" button as she points back to the m TIFFANY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But stupid quizzes can be illustrative of potential relationship problems. (to her caller)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, I'm getting the feeling this is an anxious day for you. Ted, cooking pot in hand, walks over to her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our only relationship problem is you're running a $1.99 a minute carny scam out of my living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call it a scam. (to the caller - startled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to learn to channel that rage, Margaret. (to Ted - playful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't just call this your living room, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant ours.  Ours, ours, ours. Tiffany returns to her call, but keeps looking at Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel someone you really care about, maybe even the love of your life, is being a real pain.  Now I need you to concentrate... Ted pretends to do just that, drawing a giggle from Tiffa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul tries to open the front door, but finds it blocked b Three good yanks and it finally opens. He enters the shop Faded travel posters cover the walls.  AVIS (40s), a care her boss as she assembles a life-size stand-up cardboard Airlines.  It features a dark Hawaiian beauty holding a softball sized sea shell. the display giving it a 3-D quality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning Mr. Barnell.  Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Avis.  Looks good. Paul, shivering, hangs up his coat as Avis picks up a pro surfboard (the old display) and walks it to the back. PAUL (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was November this bad last year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if we didn't have the weather what would we talk about?  Did you send the computer back? Paul moves to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was not working.  Any calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that fellow from Municipal Power and Electric.  I told him you sent the check in weeks ago, but some people don't like to listen. Paul turns to look at the snow covered empty parking lot, wife Margaret on his desk.  He mentally gathers himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something... strange happened last night Avis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did... you ever meet my brother Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one who went missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.  Well anyway last night there's a knock on the door and there's Raymond, just... standing there on the doorstep. Avis arrives with the coffee and the mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you have him declared...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead?  No.  I mean, they said he hadn't been gone long enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling warmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing in hindsight. Paul puts the mail down on the desk and start to flip thr most marked past due.  He finds a "pre- approved" credit it to one side. AVIS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where was he all these years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower 48.  Said he wanted to get away from the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where 'bouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, what was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was he living? Paul, a flash of panic, looks over at the Hawaii display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an aunt down there.  Where 'bouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blanking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A uh... small place.  By the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's great.  You and Mrs. Barnell will have some company for a bit I guess.  How is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better, a little better.  Some days are better than others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET BARNELL (early 40s) stands in a plush bathrobe a Despite her casual attire she is immaculately made up as front door, opening it on -- a young wholesome PAPERBOY s cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collecting, Mrs. Barnell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel, you pussy little cocksucker.  I'll get my purse. The paperboy, unfazed, smiles as Margaret walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 12 dollars.  I missed you last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerk off... OK, jerk off, uhhuh... Margaret gives the paperboy his money, the stamp card plu tweaks his nose.  Twice. MARGARET (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say hi to your slut Mom for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure will.  Thanks. He trots down the walk as Margaret shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lid opens.  GARY and JIMBO (30s), check to insure the watched.  Gary, slightly effeminate, leans into the bin a the garbage.  Jimbo, a bear of man, keeps watch.  He's ne sorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought stuff didn't smell when it was frozen?  I don't know why we have to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave wants visual confirmation, he gets visual confirmation.  We have a chance to move up here, so let's just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the guy's not gonna end up in a land- fill, anyway.  You ever ask Dave what he did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it was, he told him if he did it again, he'd snap his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops, he did it again. (off Jimbo not getting it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song?  From that girl? No response.  Gary, HUMMING now, keeps digging, finding n GARY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how'd it feel?  I mean, not when you did it, but, like now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about it. Gary hops inside as his actions become more frantic.  Sti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here. Jimbo glares at his partner. GARY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serious.  He's gone.  Maybe he wasn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even joke.  Maybe the trash was emptied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks pretty full.  Hey... (ducking down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a little fridge down here. (standing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we would have shot him at least we'd know for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was following orders.  And if you hadn't started a screaming match, no one would have called the cops and we wouldn't have had to dump his --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying... maybe you didn't break it all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying... maybe it was like hypothermia and he just looked dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It - was - BROKEN! Gary, embarrassed, digs in the trash with his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, still in her bathrobe, walks to the fridge.  As latch, she notices the pile of pop cans on the floor. She tugs on the door.  It opens just a crack before the c frozen head peeks through the slight gap. Margaret SIGHS, tries to push the fridge door closed, but She gives the door a hip check.  The door latches shut wh and brittle inside CRACKS.  Margaret, oblivious, walks aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chicken sits in a pan, the rest of the room visible beh door window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?  Why is the fridge in the garage chained shut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my Angel tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blow me.  Dinner's almost ready.  You feel like some wine?  I feel like some wine. Paul walks to the oven, opens the door and pats the chick

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, here's a crazy thought... I don't feel like chicken tonight, why don't we order in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
